review_text: Does The Crimson Court make the game harder? Yes. Are the mechanics of the Crimson Curse annoying to micromanage? Yes. Overall, is the DLC well designed? No. BUT, does it make the game more fun to play? Also no.

Once you start this DLC you NEED to finish it. You can dance around the other DLC(Color of Madness) if you're stubborn and Butcher's Circus is completely optional. This is not. This is a 'I beat the game and want to do something new!' not a 'this will integrate well with my experience once I start getting level whatever heroes consistently and master some mechanics'. I will show up at your home on my hands and knees begging you to not enable this DLC until you are endgame or near it. Monsters from this DLC can appear in other dungeons and while it's not guaranteed the Crimson Curse is pretty easily transmissible, and it's effect are very hard to deal with when your roster starts getting more and more infected with limited supplies to deal with it. Frankly it's really easy for Crimson Court to overwhelm your game, even softlock you.

I started it on a file where I had already beaten the game and I actually found it really engaging. A infectious disease DOES spread like wildfire, it DOES make sense close quarters might spread it, disease spreading rampantly and dominating my town DOES make sense to me, you DO need to mitigate or treat a disease and it's more negatives than positives(unless you're metagaming and optimizing). I though it was very cool. I thought the enemies were very cool. If I was unfortunate enough to play it early-mid game I can see it completely ruining things for me. The repetition is also an issue and I personally really hate an invitation mechanic. It forces you to grind even longer for a chance at progressing the plot. I would get this on sale exclusively AFTER you've beaten the game or are at the endgame.

Generic tips and tricks for the interested:

-Please don't do it man, take the left mouse button off your finger on the DLC enable screen man, it's not worth it yet. Beat the game or get to endgame first

-Be prepared for the Crimson Curse to dominate your roster eventually. I kept a dedicated team to rotate in and out with strict placement to avoid the spread, flat out fleeing combat with anything that might infect others

-The Flagellant is a very interesting and cool new character to have on your team. I think his presence alone made the DLC much more engaging

-There are certain trinkets that are borderline mandatory to defeat the last boss, and there is not a guarantee you will get all of them before having the opportunity to fight. Be aware there is an optimal way to do it

I feel conflicted about this DLC.

On one hand, it introduces a new region with cool map mechanics, a new hero, and a ton of interesting monsters. On the other hand, this expansion does the cardinal sin of mixing DLC content with base game content. The end result is that Crimson Court's monsters, of which there are many annoying ones, eventually flood all other regions.

My advice? Beat the base game first, and only then activate the Crimson Court.

While I can understand the mixed reception I think this is ultimately a pretty great DLC. If i had to guess, the disconnect between those who like it and those who do not might largely comes from 2 elements: 1. The Fanatic and Investation feel cheap to the new player with how hard it can be to avoid infection and not take infected party members with you on quests at times and 2. Crimson Court's content warping the game around it rather than enhancing the base game.

My thoughts are as follows:
1. Yes, the Fanatic absolutely is cheap and frankly, I don't like his inclusion in his current state. He is my major problem with  this DLC because unlike other RNG mechanics like The Things From The Stars or Bloodsucker encounters, he feels nearly impossible to be prepared for at all times. Crimson Curse can spread so fast due to infestation that it is not an uncommon occurrence that an average skill player will *have* to take infected party members with them for a decent composition. However, having a decent composition that is *also* good at staying healthy AND fighting off the Fanatic is a big ask for something that is completely up to chance. Compare this to The Thing From The Stars, who is also a random encounter but is shown to roam one specific area on the map at a time. This means that if your current available party members are not good at fighting him, you can simply avoid that area for the time being. The Fanatic is ALWAYS there, can show up at any point during most quests so long as one VERY common condition is met, and he is extremely dangerous. It's not very fun, especially for players new to the DLC.

2. I feel the rest is a general disconnect between a decent part of the playerbase and what I believe Red Hook was trying to accomplish with the DLC. I think *because* it is paid DLC many people might come into Crimson Court with the expectation that since they had a pay a decent amount for it, this is content *any* darkest dungeon will be able to enjoy rather than a rework of the main campaign designed for hardcore fans to make an already hard game EVEN harder. The game warns you that this is not the case, and that you should play this only after beating a regular campaign, and I do wonder how many of the players who walked away disliking the DLC took this warning seriously seeing as quite a few Crimson Court DLC achievements have a higher completion rate than beating the base game on Radiant, or how many base game players really tried to change and adapt their playstyle to fit the new challenges and needs the DLC presents. Infestation can seem annoying or unfair at first, but focusing on collecting a significant amount of trinkets that buff your units against bloodsuckers specifically will help out a lot when dealing with these additional random encounters, while also increasing your ability to deal with threats in the Courtyard. The Crimson Curse is also a new thing you'll have to manage and outside of the Fanatic I think it is an interesting mechanic that adds another level of inventory and item management, and as long as you recognize the necessity to rush the Sanguine Vinters, which produces two vials of blood each week, this too never gets too overwhelming from my experience.

On top of this, the Crimson Court adds incredibly engaging lore, a really cool aesthetic, an interesting new area (although I hate the crocodilian boss and the Epic length layouts are probably a bit **too** long) If you treat the DLC for what it is, that being a harder, new way to experience the Darkest Dungeon campaign, I think it succeeds at that exceptionally well.

Also the Flagellant rules what a sick character whose role as a bleed stacker with consistent, strong healing opens up so many more teamcomps. If you enjoyed your playthrough of the base game and are looking for a different take on it, definitely get Crimson Court. Otherwise, you are probably better off waiting for a sale and buying the DLC for cheap for the Flagellant (who can be enabled seperately from the Crimson Court campaign).

I think the mixed reviews are deserved.  

Good:
The bosses are very difficult and the new dungeons are massive and persistent (you can leave and come back).  Neat to go through.  Note that the first visit is just a normal dungeon, not persistent.

Bad:
There's a lot of padding/grinding.  Each visit to the crimson court requires an invitation.  To get an invitation, you need to wait for your town infestation to grow to high.  Takes several weeks.  Then you need to go into a dungeon and hope to find a gatekeeper.  Kill the gatekeeper before he runs away, and you got an invitation.  You can't store invitations, because each boss requires a new type of invitation. 

Repeat this process every time you want to make progress in the new massive persistent dungeon.  You'll spend more time grinding invitations than clearing the Crimson Court.  This is not good design.

After finishing the game a long time ago without this DLC enabled, I decided to play this game again, but this time with Crimson Court, without any prior knowledge of this DLC. At first, I enjoyed the DLC because I had played the game before, and the new mechanics brought a fresh breeze and a new challenge to the game, but around the late midgame I started to hate it so much. First of all, the Crimson Curse is not entirely bad, when your characters go into Bloodlust, it’s actually a buff, and a pretty good one nonetheless. HOWEVER, it’s incredibly annoying to micromanage, and even more so when a lot of your people have it, because that means doing Crimson Court dungeons and wasting your time to get enough blood vials so your people don’t die, which can happen.
Now, the second thing that pissed me off are the enemies, with many of them being able to randomly infect your heroes with the Crimson Curse. Now, that wouldn’t be too bad if they were restricted to the new Crimson Court area, BUT THEY AREN’T. EVERY TIME I GO INTO A DUNGEON, I HAVE TO FIGHT THOSE CUNTS ON MULTIPLE OCCASIONS, RISKING MORE PEOPLE GETTING INFECTED EVERY TIME. And not just that, they are purposefully made as annoying as possible to fight against, having high dodge and high speed.
But let’s say you don’t mind that too much and would still like to experience this DLC. Then enjoy doing the new, amazing, EPIC length dungeons, which are about as enjoyable as inserting broken glass up your anus. To some extent, I understand the decision to add something new, but they really messed up with the new EPIC dungeons. Overall, I wouldn’t recommend this DLC unless you really like hurting yourself. Almost everything it adds just leads to a worse experience of the game, so… just don’t.

This is one of the shittiest DLCs I've ever had the displeasure of playing. The Crimson Court starts off as something quite interesting, giving us a completely new area, new enemies, new trinkets, and most importantly, the Crimson Curse mechanic.

This mechanic serves as a sort of "vampire disease" that your heroes can get by being infected by the new enemies from the DLC. But the thing is, once they have it, you can't just cure it like you would other diseases, matter of fact I haven't even reached that point in my current (blind) playthrough of the DLC so I'm not even sure how much work it takes to get rid of this thing. What I DO know is how fucking annoying it gets and how much it halts your gameplay completely, almost ruining the whole experience.

Look, I love Darkest Dungeon. It's the first turn-based game I've ever actually tried and enjoyed, but this shit SUCKS. First of all, the Crimson Curse isn't something you can just leave there. Not only is it uncurable by normal means, but it constantly fucks with your heroes by simply being there. It starts off as quite interesting, but unravels into a mess of unfun bullshit.
Getting Blood is annoying as shit because the enemies are annoying as shit, they're repetitive and boring and way too powerful in certain situations, but worse than that, they're fucking everywhere. You can't even avoid them properly because the damn bastards start infecting other areas, making fighting them (and therefore getting heroes infected) basically unavoidable.

But not just that, even if you go through all these hurdles and get the Blood, the resource you need to keep your people from NOT DYING, it still sucks ass because of how erratic they become when infected. No matter the current stage of the Curse they're on, they're basically a walking stress nuke. Craving makes them attack other heroes or even themselves, act like idiots and deal stress damage to the party, Wasting makes them want to die and most of the time they'll straight up PASS THEIR TURN because fuck you (which can be LITERALLY fatal in certain situations), and even while they're in the supposed "best stage", which is Bloodlust, they're still unstable and stupid, since they might start acting on their own or say more dumb shit that deals stress damage to the whole party. There is a 25% damage buff that accompanies this bullshit, but to me, that IS NOT worth the hassle. I'd rather get my damage from LITERALLY anything else than get it like this and fuck my entire game.

I still haven't been able to cure any of my heroes. The new mission, while interesting, is WAY too fucking long. I get the idea of making a big mission where you get to leave and come back and it's a big arc and all that, but all of this shit combined, the shitty Blood stages, the annoying enemies, the unavoidability of the whole thing, all those things together, make an extremely unpleasant experience that gets really close to ruining Darkest Dungeon's gameplay loop.

With all that said, there are reasons why you should still buy this DLC, that being the new class exclusive to it, the Flagellant. The Flagellant is one of the most creative classes the game has to offer, being a bleeder/support who can input extremely high amounts of bleed while also healing the team at the same time, which he does by being extremely masochistic, becoming stronger as his health depletes, even taking his own health by self-bleed so he can, in turn, heal the others. He gets even stronger if he gets to death's door, gaining damage, speed and crit buffs while in this state, while also unlocking new abilities while at lower health thresholds. He is also the only character in the game to be unaffected by mortality debuffs. This is an extremely fun character to play with and the best part is you can turn him on while leaving the DLC off, so buying it can be worth it you want the Flagellant in your game. If he was a separate DLC, I'd recommend the shit out of that, but as it stands, I have to come here to speak my mind about the bloodletting enthusiast.

It's an incredible game, but this DLC only soils the experience.

This DLC is a weird one, granted all the complaints and salt about it were (and to some degree still are) completely justified. However, most of the issued have been ironed out, but I shall go into detail in regard to them later. First I have to say that at the current state the DLC is well worth it, with a huge "BUT" to consider first though. 

Now, a little bit of spoilers about it (not that it really matters in 2020), it's important to note that this DLC, once started, will inflict an affliction onto your roster, which if you are not prepared, can stress you out by outright threatening your roster to die out due to the Crimson Curse. However, the issue is not as prevailing as it used to be, infected heroes will need blood every couple weeks / dungeon runs, if they go for too long without it (3 checks / graving) they WILL die as a result. 
Fortunately the blood is no longer hard to come by as it used to be (which is the reason for the majority of negative reviews btw), so there are a couple of counter-measures that should be established before heading into the first Crimson Court mission.

[b](Again little bit of spoilers, but this is information one NEEDS to know if one is to actually enjoy this DLC)[/b]

-Hold off from actually starting the first CC mission until you are well established ( small cash reserve and the Sanguine Vitner building which will produce 2 blood every week, allowing you to maintain almost a dozen heroes without the stress of them dying.
-Once the Curse afflicted your roster, supply runs can be launched to stock up on blood
-Drinking holy water reduces the change of heroes getting afflicted by the CC
-Putting cursed heroes into buildings with non-cursed ones WILL spread the curse in the hamlet
-Defeating a boss in the Crimson Court cures all heroes
-Bringing cursed heroes into regular mission will trigger a chance of them being hunted by a wandering boss (you will be warned in the loading screen if he is present tho), so make sure you are prepared facing that threat
-Defeating the final boss of the Crimson Court allows you to cure the Crimson Curse in your Sanatorium whenever you want.

[b]Now to some negatives that still affect the game / DLC:[/b]

-Once you go into the Courtyard, the CC enemies will infest ALL other areas of the game, meaning you will be put on time pressure to clear a courtyard boss after a couple of normal missions, because more and more of your roster will become afflicted.
-The Crimson Court opens up to early for how difficult it is, stressing out newer, unprepared players by forcing all the mechanics onto them if they thought they could tackle the thing.
-The dungeons are a tad bit too big, I had to refer to the revealed maps online so I don't walk circles and dead ends for HOURS due to back tracking / locked gates


[b]Now to the goods, and why it's definitely worth to get:[/b]

-Districts, for very useful and cool bonuses 
-Very cool enemy design and theme
-Flagellant new class which is fun and unique to use
-Entirely different from the base game in terms of how the dungeons are structured and tackled
-Very useful trinkets which provide additional set bonuses 
-Once you got the hang of the game, it still offers a fun challenge after 100+ hours

All in all, I didnt regret jumping into the DLC in the long run, while I initially considered deleting my save file and starting over for how overwhelmed and stressed out I was when the DLC forced all its mechanics on me after I foolishly went into the first Courtyard mission with little preparedness. Now I have finished the whole thing and I am glad I stuck to it and duked it out.

If you haven't played this game before, DO NOT ENABLE CRIMSON COURT CONTENT. The warning about it being for experienced players isn't a joke. The Crimson Court adds an interesting, challenging, and frankly desperately needed mid-game objective for veteran players that requires resource and roster management to conquer effectively. If you want to get the dlc for your first playthrough, DISABLE CRIMSON COURT, keep on districts and flagellant until you beat the base game AT LEAST ONCE. There are enough negative reviews on a perfectly good expansion that people don't need to give it more bad ratings because it doesn't hold their hands.

Flagellant: 
Great class, fantastic to have another healer on the roster, really unique playing front liner with heals, bleed, and high risk/reward content with abilities that only activate at low HP threshholds. A lot of fun to play with. Only real downside is that he only uses Flagellation Hall for stress relief so you'll want to upgrade that early if you plan on using him.

Districts: 
Fantastic addition, great mid to late game resource dump for when you start accumulating lots of money once you've upgraded all your buildings and don't have to spend as much on your heroes. They give passive bonuses for your town or party members. Not a whole lot to say, just good to have another upgrade path.

Crimson Court:
For better or for worse, game changing. The concept is simple: There's a huge, sprawling new area called the Crimson Court, a new enemy class called Bloodsuckers, and a new game mechanic called the Crimson Curse. The Curse is contracted through certain attacks Bloodsuckers have and can't be cured like other diseases, and cursed heroes require a new item, The Blood, almost constantly, or they risk dying on expeditions or cursing your other heroes when idle in town. This isn't for casuals. It really makes you play differently, wondering whether it'll be worth it to keep a good hero on your roster if it'll risk compromising the rest of the adventurers and prioritising bringing your most valuable heroes to boss fights to kill Crimson Court bosses, which cures the Curse. As you progress through the Court, Bloodsuckers start showing up in other areas in increasingly large numbers, resulting in every expedition becoming riskier the longer you leave the Court unattended, with the final reward being the ability to cure the Curse at the Sanitarium, like any other disease. 

All in all, Crimson Court gives Darkest Dungeon's midgame the kick in the ass it desperately needed. If you're a fan of darkest dungeon, don't listen to casual players badmouthing the expansion just because it wasn't what they wanted. Give it a chance, and you might be surprised how intense it gets.

Don't listen to the salty reviews, but be warned if you decide to enable this DLC for your first playthrough. It is hard. It will affect your progression through the campaign. Whether you're a new player wanting to give it a try or someone looking to try it out on a second playthrough, here are seven bits of advice from someone who's been playing with CC enabled from the beginning:

1. The Flagellant is worth the price of admission alone. He's a frontline healer with powerful damage over time in the form of bleed and the ability to transfer other party members' stress to himself (and he has an inexpensive camp skill that reduces his stress by a ton). He's good in any area except the Ruins. Don't sleep on Reclaim and Redeem, as they are powerful healing skills. Reclaim is not affected by healing skill buffs or debuffs.

2. Don't feel pressured to do the first Courtyard quest as soon as the town event "The Town is Abuzz" takes place. It will slightly lower the stress heal your heroes get from activities, but you can sit on that for as long as you want until you feel ready to start the Courtyard's questline. Personally I would recommend going in with a party of level 2 characters. After you complete this first quest, you gain an "infestation level". The higher it is, the more often Courtyard enemies will start showing up in other areas.

3. If you need Blood for your Cursed characters, there is always a short quest available in the Courtyard called "Gather the Blood" that will net you about 12 with each expedition. You can also build the Sanguine Vintners district, which will add two bottles of Blood to your stock each week for free.

4. The Fanatic is a powerful roaming boss who shows up with a town event when you reach Medium infestation. If you take two or more Cursed characters to a regular dungeon, there's a chance he will follow you in and stalk you. If you aren't specifically geared to fight the Fanatic, just leave. The game will warn you if he's in the dungeon with you with a special loading screen. He won't show up if you have only one party member with the Crimson Curse. He can't show up on boss quests or in the Courtyard, so send all your cursed party members there for XP.

5. You may notice you need "invitations" to enter the Crimson Court's Epic quests. These items are dropped by Gatekeepers, which have a chance to spawn as part of any Courtyard mash that appears in a normal biome. They tend to run on Turn 2 and are very fast, so prioritize killing them if you want the drop. The cocoon curio that appears at higher infestation levels will always spawn a Gatekeeper, so that's a semi-reliable way of farming invitations if you need them.

6. Bring lots of food, Blood, Torches, and Shovels to Crimson Court Epic quests. Don't bother bringing any keys, since the special chests that are supposed to give you Crimson Court trinkets will just give you normal loot instead if you use a key on them. Courtyard is always considered to be at 100% torch, but torches are used to clear obstacles, interact with curios, and provide a temporary accuracy buff to your whole party. Shovels are used to smash certain curios that will give you firewood to camp. Don't be afraid of leaving early. The game doesn't expect you to finish it in a single week. If you have a lot of good loot, feel free to abandon the quest. When you return, you'll be in the same place you left off.

7. There's no shame in installing mods to tune the experience to your liking, just like the rest of Darkest Dungeon. Don't let elitists tell you that doing so is "wrong" or somehow an incorrect way to play the game.

I hope this review-slash-guide was helpful and encourages you to give Crimson Court a try despite the naysayers. I have, and it's provided me with tens of hours of fun!

Oh god, what happened here?

The Crimson Court DLC adds five news things to the base game: a handful of ancestral trinkets that operate like a "set" bonus in a hack-n-slash, a new character called The Flagellant, a new debuff called The Crimson Curse that is essentially vampirism, a new roaming boss called The Fanatic, and the eponoymous Crimson Court area, 

Let's break down these things and discuss how every single one of these new things is ultimately flawed and makes the game WORSE.


First, the ancestral trinkets are all fairly weak, or they require strange positioning to work properly, such as your Vestal being in position 2, where she can't use her best healing, but this also buffs her Divine Comfort. So...why put your healer in harm's way to buff a worse ability, when she could be in the back and use both? The Abomination set requires him to be in the first position for a damage buff. You know, where he can't use most of his not-transformed abilities. Some are pretty solid, but the base trinkets are almost universally better, and the odds on getting both trinkets for one class is extremely low.


Second, The Flagellant. Basic logic would say that this is a character that maybe gets stronger as his health gets low. Well, kind of. He gains a damage buff when below 33% health. Problem is, his damage isn't good. However, ALL of his damage abilities cause excessive amounts of Bleed damage, making him very powerful in most areas. He also creates a healing nova on death (?!) and heals even more when at Death's Door (?!) and has both a personal heal and can heal others if his health is low. So, this means that The Flagellant has a bunch of skills that seem like they were designed by five different people in five different rooms, a buff that doesn't effect him, debuffs that further lower his damage (But not his Bleed!), and this leads to him being essentially a necessary pick. I'm not opposed to having extremely good characters in this game, but just nothing about him makes sense other than "Position 1, hit enemy until they take 20 Bleed damage per round, heal self to full if about to die".


Third, The Crimson Curse. The logic behind this is that your characters will need a new item called The Blood. If they don't get this item, they die. You have almost no options to deal with this except being forced to go to the Crimson Court, which is about as fun as a stick in the eye for reasons I'll explain later. The Crimson Curse is caused by new roaming monsters that can appear anywhere. Normally, these fights are just a lttle bit tougher than other enemies at the same level, and that's kind of cool. However, the most common new enemy is called The Sycophant, a giant mosquito. They have extremely high speed, so they always go first, extremely high dodge, so they survive much longer than is necessary, can cause stress and high amounts of bleed, as well as have the highest chance to cause Crimson Curse. Once again, there is nothing you can do about this. You get into a fight, better flip a coin that it's not Crimson Curse monsters (and by that, I mean their spawn rate is so ridicously high, I can say, without exaggeration, about half of your fights in the game will be these things), then flip another that you won't recieve a nearly permanent debuff. Even worse, this waters down the creature pool, because they can spawn anywhere, drastically limiting unique and fun party compositions because you constantly have to plan around the Crimson Court monsters. Sound like fun? Because it's not. The Crimson Curse is also spread by characters sharing buildings with each other during stress relief, so you'll start putting one character at a time in a building, slowing the game's pace to a crawl for fear of making the problem worse. Oh, but that's not all Crimson Curse does that is about as fun as licking a piece of steel wool...

Fourth, The Fanatic. If you take more than one character with The Crimson Curse into a dungeon, you have a large chance that The Fanatic will follow you in. Like The Collector or Shambler, The Fanatic appears randomly instead of a normal group of enemies. Once again, cool idea, like you're being hunted by a vampire hunter. The issue is that The Fanatic is completely unbalanced on a very basic level. He always begins with surprise for arbitrary difficulty increase. Begins the battle with "Sentence Rendered", removing one of your characters from the battle and attaching them to a burning stake, not unlike the Hag battle with her cauldron. You have an arbalist in the back? Too bad. He get your healer? You just lost. Why do you lose? Well, he gets three actions per round! Why? Arbitrary difficulty! Stress damage, bleed damage, stress over time, party removal, The Fanatic is easily the hardest fight in the game, drops the mostly terrible Crimson Court trinkets and a SINGLE USE Crimson Curse Cure. There is literally no reason to fight him. He's not impossible, just frustrating, boring, random, and pointless. It's more expedient to just leave the dungeon if the game says he's followed you in, and when I DON'T WANT TO EXPERIENCE CONTENT I PAYED FOR, there's a problem.

Then, we come to The Crimson Court itself. The main problem with the Crimson Court is that there are three (technically four) levels to it. Unlike the other areas of the game, these areas have the same map every single time, and you're expected to go as far as you can, then retreat and return with a different party where you left off. This is really cool the first time, but every subsequent time, you find yourself just rolling your eyes and looking up the map online. Otherwise, there is a lot of time backtracking through empty rooms, looking for that one room you missed that has the key in it, so you can walk all the way back, to open a door, and do it again, ending with a pretty neat boss for every level. It isn't as bad as the other problems, but it's tedious, boring, and the only pluses to doing so are...Crimson Court trinkets, and every level cures everyone in your party of Crimson Curse. 

So, let's recap. A permanent debuff caused by roaming mobs that you can't stop because they attack first, which causes a roaming boss to attack that is ridiculously unbalanced to the rest of the game, and the only way to stop it is to go into an area that causes the curse MORE OFTEN, that is boring to play, to get trinkets that aren't very good, and the main reason to do it at all is to GET RID OF THE PERMANENT DEBUFF IN THE FIRST PLACE. This means that the DLC is a giant cycle to FIX PROBLEMS THAT IT INTRODUCED. 

Sorry, but that sucks. This DLC isn't fun, it weighs the entire game down with unncessary frustration and flow-breaking mechanics, fails to create a proper ticking clock to encourage exploration, and literally the BEST part is that you can turn off the Crimson Court, but keep The Flagellant. Don't get me wrong, it's not like the DLC is broken or too difficult, it just isn't fun on a fundamental level. 

Without a major overhaul, this DLC is dead on arrival, period.

The Crimson Court is a DLC for [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] that adds A new Hero, new special Hero trinkets, a new Region (The Courtyard), new bosses, new enemies (some that can even "overflow" to other regions), a new mission type (epic... no, they're REALLY called "epic"), districts (handy little buildings that can be built to help in expeditions and other things) and, among other things, a new terrible disease... A sickness so virulent, so insidious, it is more a curse than a mere disease... and also a heavy annoyance that this DLC brings among many other things.

The new Hero is called Flagellant and he truly is a depiction of a "High-Risk, High-Reward" character, being able to take on harm to help other Heroes, having powerful abilities only able to be used at low health, and, when stressed ("Rapturous", a unique affliction that's the only possible outcome to hitting 100 Stress with the Flagellant), receiving a neat buff to damage, the Flagellant is a character that truly feels different from the usual.

Now this is where things take a change for the worst (or at least stop being completely positive).

This DLC really only "starts" once you take on the first mission at the Courtyard, where it basically shows you the ropes while giving some (unexpected) challenges for your team. And as soon as you complete this mission things will change drastically. Enemies from the Courtyard will start appearing in other regions, which would be ok, considering the whole "infestation" aspect of this DLC, but they are annoying because of 3 things: Stress (almost EVERY enemy in this DLC just loves to stress your team), Chevaliers (Yes, I made a separate comment for those guys. They're VERY annoying, hitting hard and debuffing your team) and the Crimson Curse. The new Disease added in this DLC. This Crimson Curse is one of the worst additions of this DLC. It's supposed to be a truly horrible disease that, although a menace, can be "useful" to some. The problem is that even when it's "useful" it still is an annoyance to your team by being basically an affliction that constantly needs to be "quelled" with The Blood (a new item this DLC brings that basically can work on some curios and is mainly used to help with heroes with the Crimson Curse), so you either make a lot of expeditions to the dangerous Courtyard in search of more vials of the damned thing, make the Sanguine Vintners to help you on the whole ordeal or you suffer by the hands of... the mosquito gods (or just goddess) and watch as your characters slowly die due to blood addiction.

Quests are so so SO long. With more than 50 (!!) rooms and even more halls, they are truly exhausting. Then they also require invitations that you can only get by killing Courtyard enemies that are roaming/breeding in other regions. 1 quest can require more than 10 different expeditions to be cleared.

Enemies are VERY annoying, which is quite fitting for half-mosquito maniacs, but they are EXTREMELY annoying. High dodge, a lot of stress attacks, the already mentioned Crimson Curse... then there's also the fact that when they use their trademark Crimson Court move, "[b]The Thirst[/b]" (and I have to praise the devs on this one, I liked how almost all of them share that particular move. It is extremely fitting), they heal, get new moves and are buffed. It's so stressful (hey!) to be close to killing that one annoying verming then having him use that move, infect your hero with the Crimson Curse and also Crit Heal to almost full health... Still though, I loved how they morph to more grotesque forms when they use (and hit) that move. The transformation is great and fitting.

Music? It's great. I love how Stuart Chatwood managed to make "buzzing" a part of the combat theme. It goes very well with the whole "mosquito infestation" theme of the DLC. Truly one of the best parts of this DLC.

The Courtyard looks amazing. A swamp that very clearly shows that once it was a place of respect now consumed by the infestation and the invading nature... so good. The soft buzzing of mosquitoes and the sound of dripping blood do wonders at establishing the themes of the DLC.

Bosses are... tough. But one that really annoyed me and I consider the strongest and most annoying of this DLC was the only one that's not even half-mosquito. Yes, I'm talking about The Fanatic. This one guy will hunt down expeditions that have Heroes with the Crimson Curse (because it was already easy enough as it was) and will absolutely be a relentless enemy or, at the Ancestor puts it: "an animal - rabid, destructive, and incapable of nuanced understanding." Capable of choosing one of your Heroes down to receive constant unstoppable damage akin to Hag's Cauldron while also dishing out constant damage, debuffs and buffing himself, he's truly one annoying maniac. If you DO defeat him, though, you'll receive 2 special items called "The Cure", which, as the name implies, can cure your Hero of the Crimson Curse once. Yay. So then you can use that useful little thing on your afflicted Jester and Highwayman on Death's Door so that you can escape the Dungeon because he absolutely destroyed your team but at least now you don't want to drink blood flavoured wine. So if you are going to a "normal" quest and have one or more heroes with the Crimson Curse I hope you are prepared for judgement.

One thing that this DLC also brings are special Hero-specific trinkets. A lot of them. 2 for each hero. We have 17 Heroes (Including the Flagellant and the Musketeer but excluding the Shieldbreaker because her Crimson Court trinkets are received through nightmares) so 17 x 2 and we have 34 trinkets. Neat. While doing Crimson Court quests you might find these special "Crimson Court" trinkets, so you slowly fill your collection of trinkets... then the "proper" Crimson Court quests end and you have to [spoiler]fight this stupidly big and buff stone statue repeatedly if you want to gather all of the remaining CC trinkets[/spoiler] which isn't much of an interesting task. What makes you hunt for the trinkets, though, is the fact that they are related to the heroes lore-wise and more lore is always nice and that they are also very powerful, giving special buffs if using both at the same time.

Even though this is a DLC that could be considered as making the game "worse", I'd be lying if I said I outright disliked it. Sure, some things are indeed annoying, some things really felt exhaustive but, in the end, I had fun. And I can understand (or at least believe I understand) why the devs made it so, although I was very close to disliking it.

That's ok. You can do that. So if you just want the Flagellant and Districts but not to drown in Blood Flavoured Wine™... you can do that. Ok DLC.

I can't recommend this DLC. I really can't. I'll give a brief summary of the things I enjoy and which I don't enjoy, but to make things short: 
It really makes the game experience worse, rather than better. 

For the positives, well... 
The new class is very nice, and enjoyable to use. It has unique mechanics and once you get the hang of him, he's a very satisfying addition to a team.
New trinkets are also nice. They add a bit more variety and expand things, rather than restrict them; this line will make sense later, when I get into the negatives.
The Districts that have been added are also a nice touch, but that's about all I can say for them; they add a little more to do and upgrade in your Hamlet. They're just little bonus points, for the most part, but it's still nice.


Alright, now to move on to the bulk of the things added by the Crimson Court... which coincidentally also brings us into the negatives.

[h1]The Crimson Curse![/h1]

Firstly, the Crimson Curse-mechanic is a plague on the gameplay. Heroes have a chance to be affected by the Crimson Curse whenever they're hit by a Bloodsucker-type enemy; the type of enemy introduced with the Crimson Court DLC.
A hero affected by the Crimson Curse will need to be fed the Blood, a specific item dropped by Crimson Court-enemies and in recently introduced missions that only serve the purpose to retrieve the Blood. If heroes can't be fed Blood, they start to wither away; their curse first worsening (adding a harsher debuff), their behavior growing more erratic (such as refusing to be healed or stressing other heroes out whenever they are hit, or investigate a curio), and finally, if they're not fed while wasting away? They die. 
Naturally, this requires you to regularly go on supply runs in the Crimson Court to retrieve Blood for your heroes. These runs don't advance anything, they're only there to get you Blood, and you are only facing Bloodsuckers, which in turn have a chance to afflict your heroes with the Crimson Curse, requiring you to run into the Court more often. Very thrilling!

As if that wasn't enough, heroes have a chance to spread their affliction to fellow heroes if they are sharing the same stress-relief activity; meaning if you put two heroes to chill at the bar, one of which is afflicted by the Crimson Curse, and a third hero to gamble, there's a high chance that Hero A will afflict Hero B at the bar.
There's also a slight chance he'll infect Hero C who is just gambling, for good measure.
Naturally, this results in you pondering whether or not you will risk putting ANY non-Crimson Curse heroes into the same building as an infected hero; and that means if one of your Crimson Curse heroes decides to have an existential crisis that causes him to not leave the bar, they'll essentially lock down the entire building for 2 weeks, because putting anyone in there will result in MORE Crimson Curse.

This wouldn't be so bad, if heroes afflicted by the Crimson Course wouldn't behave like aggressive drug addicts that occasionally beat up their team members and drool over every injury inflicted. However, to make things worse, there's also a completely psychopathic "miniboss", the Fanatic, which has a chance to spawn if your group in a dungeon has heroes afflicted by the Crimson Curse. He's a rather challenging boss, and while hard to beat, he can actually drop pretty good stuff; except for a mediocre trinket that increases a heroes damage against the Fanatic and the Fanatic alone.

So you're starting to see why the Crimson Curse becomes a problem. It makes your heroes act completely idiotic in very frustrating ways, requires you to run missions that have a high chance of getting more heroes inflicted, and makes it so you can't have your heroes relax freely, because if you do so, they'll afflict even more heroes with Terminal Addiction Disease, AKA the Crimson Curse.

But hey, that all sounds like it needs to snowball, right? 
Wrong.
Which leads us to the next point, the 
[h1]Crimson Court[/h1]

Crimson Court-missions are classified as "Epic". The Dungeons are meant to be long, challenging runs, that you keep interrupting and re-entering to make sure you're in top condition as you work your way towards the boss, unlocking color-coded doors as you go. The problem is that you can't freely re-enter on a whim, you require invitations. But how do you get invitations? Well, simple. You kill Gatekeepers! Gatekeepers are spawned in regular levels, sometimes. And what sounds like careful management of ressources, to see if you can't just push the run in the Court a little longer and risk facing harsh conditions because you just don't have any more invitations is actually just a chore.

In the background of your normal missions, the Infestation of Bloodsuckers constantly builds; as it reaches its peak, you get at least one group of Bloodsuckers in any dungeon you run. I at least get two on average, in a short dungeon. One time I got 4 groups of Bloodsuckers. 
Yes, this means that you can potentially face more Bloodsuckers than the enemy-type you're expected to face in a dungeon. 
And yes, they can also cause Crimson Curse.
These groups also don't have much variety, which means you'll eventually KNOW what a group of Bloodsuckers will do ahead of time, but you won't be able to prevent it. 
And what's the only way to get the Infestation-level lower? You probably guessed it: Finish the "Epic" quest, and slay the boss, to get a brief respite from the Crimson Curse and the Bloodsuckers from over at the Crimson Court.

So you end up with an overabundance of Crimson Curse-afflicted heroes, requiring you to run short Crimson Court-missions to get your Blood, where more heroes will get afflicted, which restricts your ability to freely let heroes relax, and also increases the odds to have to face a psychopath that has a fetish for burning people on a pyre, all the while groaning in frustration as you face another set of mosquitos to get your 900th invitation to the Crimson Court where you can run around in an [strike]overly long[/strike] Epic quest where you hope you don't die of alligators.

And that sums up my problem with the Crimson Court DLC: 
It doesn't really expand the core gameplay, as much as it overwrites it. It creeps into your gameplay like a set of horrible, blood-red strangling. It seems horrifying at first, because of the interesting concept, but you soon realize it's more and more of a nuisance that just keeps you from doing the things you might actually WANT to do. The Crimson Curse and the Crimson Court try to hog the spotlight in the worst of ways; by pushing aside the basics, and replacing them with increasingly frustrating, and less varying mechanics. 

Now, the fellows over at Red Hook are obviously still ironing things out, so this MIGHT change; chances of enemies infecting heroes have been tinkered with, and the acquisiton of Blood has also already been worked on (though in my opinion, the change was alright at best). So there is still hope for the Bloodsuckers to end up something fun and interesting.

The Crimson Court isn't for everybody. It isn't for people who are already struggling a bit too much with the main game. It's for people who are looking to add a new layer of difficulty on top of what's already on the table, and I do think that Devs should have clarified that a bit.

Now that being said, I don't think it's badly designed or unrewarding at all. I honestly never start a new campaign without the Crimson Court because after a ton of hours the base game can't keep up with it's veteran players.

A lot of the negative reviews seem to be caused by frustration and I understand being tired of setbacks but that's exactly what the game is trying to do. They want you to fail at some point to learn from what you did wrong and they want you to overcome something that defeated you beforehand. This is the has been the design philosophy of DD and this DLC only expands on it. They are putting new roadblocks for you to fail, only to be conquered later.

This review may be a bit late with Darkest Dungeon 2 coming to steam in a few months but I wanted to write it anyway

Steam is in desperate need of a 'Mixed' option.

I have nothing but good things to say about the base game. The expansion is not bad either, but there are so many questionable design decisions you wonder why the Dev's chose to release it in its state.

Before I get to the positives, there are quite a few negatives to get out of the way.

- Poor implementation: This expansion should be gated to a certain stage of your Hamlet as most newer playthroughs will have a hard time dealing with the new challenge of managing the Crimson Curse. While it is not impossible to deal with if the Hamlet is not fully upgraded, it is harder when the curse spreads and you only have so much blood. You are forced to go out on "Wine runs" to get more. This affects the overall pacing and delays progress.

- Epic Dungeons: I actually didn't mind these at first, until I discovered that they are not randomly generated and have dead ends that can take up to 15 minutes to return to the correct path (why is this acceptable?). This wouldn't be such a bad thing if there were lots of new enemies to keep the runs interesting, but you'll have met just about every monster type within the first 5 minutes of your "Champion" epic run. I guess their length does add to the bleak feel of the expansion, but it could be so much leaner/punchier.

- Put the hardest boss on the first "Crimson Curse lifted" event: Not talking about the Crocadillian, though he can be a pest on higher difficulties, I'm talking about The Baron. While the fight is fun and the gimmick is really interesting, you will only be successfull with certain compositions as The Baron has far too many turns and health. This wouldn't be so bad if it was on Champion level, but he is on Veteran which mean't I had to level up a new team from scratch to take him on successfully. I believe he could have worked better as the Boss before the Countess as The Viscount is laughably easy.

- The Fanatic : Disappears after you've beaten the Countess. He was such a cool wandering boss and I'm actually sad that there's no other way to trigger his event.

- Nothing much to do after the Countess is beaten: You now have an easy way to address the annoying curse, but you'll almost never use it as the CC monsters never stray outside of the Courtyard. Should you decide to revist the Courtyard, you'll have the option of repeatedly fighting the The Garden Guardian; probably one of the least entertaining fights in the entire game. There is little incentive to return to the courtyard because of this reason.

All of these negatives could have been addressed if the Epic quests were shorter and more focused, Boss order was rejigged, roaming still exists after beating CC and maybe a few monster additions to keep things feeling fresh. For the endgame (intead of the Garden Guardian), even if they recycled base game Bosses with a Crimson twist, it would have made for more interesting grinding.

In summary, I'd much rather have a shorter but sweet experience instead of feeling like I've seen it all within the first 20 minutes of playing. 



Now for the positives:
- Flagellant: Easily one of the most versitile classes in the game. A healer and a tank that almost never dies? I'll take ten.
- Districts: Now you can take all the useless artifacts that pile up and apply them to new buildings that give perma stat bonuses. A great way to give you something to work towards when most of the content has been explored
- Story and the atmosphere were great additions. It defintely left me wanting more.
- The countess fight was unique and tense. Just wish there was some kind of endgame cutscene to resolve her death.
- Music and Art are strong as always. I really hope there is a way to get an artwork book for the expansions, similar to the base game.


Overall: Great additions to the base game at the cost of some repetition to get the full experience. For its price, it's not a bad purchase. Just be sure you know what you're getting into before you enable the content as it may create some unfavorable playthroughs.

I was long putting off getting this DLC because the reviews were making it sound very bad, but after asking around on the forums and deciding to finally get it, I am glad that I did. I'm going to break down each aspect of the DLC for those who are unsure as I was.

First of all, you don't have to do the Courtyard missions right away at the start of your DD campaign. When in the campaign screen, you can choose which aspects of this DLC to activate. So you can activate the Flagellant class and the Districts right away and then leave the Courtyard for later if you so choose (or not at all!).

The Courtyard area itself is pretty well made in my opinion and is somewhat different to the main 4 areas in the base game. The main missions that have a boss at the end (of which there are 3; not counting the intro mission) are enormous sprawling dungeons that require more than one entry and a party regroup, so you're not likely to beat each one in a single expedition. They have entirely new curios to interact with, and the torchlight mechanic is not present here. 

The DLC also introduces a bunch of new enemies, the bloodsuckers. They usually appear in the Courtyard. However, as the infestation grows, they will start appearing in other areas of the game as well. Some people have said it's repetitive to fight them as there are only about 6-7 of these new regular enemies that keep coming up a lot, but I personally did not find them too repetitive as they come up in different team compositions which might require you to adjust your strategies. Moreover, these enemies also have 2 forms. If they happen to drink blood of one of your heroes, they change into a more hideous form and have a new look and new attacks.

Perhaps the thing that was offputting me the most about getting this DLC is the infamous Crimson Curse, which your heroes can get infected with, which makes them crave blood. However, after having played through this DLC, the curse mechanic is actually not so bad at all. The debuffs the curse causes are very minor (it's more like a double-edged sword actually and can be made to work in your favour), and the blood craving can be temporarily satiated by blood vials that drop very frequently. In fact you can even take your party to a blood-gathering quest to collect many of those blood vials. I did those 2-3 times, and together with blood found from other, more random sources, I ended up having a huge stack of 30 blood vials before I even took down the first Courtyard boss. By the time I went for the final boss of the DLC, this stack of blood grew to 50 vials. So fear not, you won't be short on blood. I've never had a hero die due to the curse.

Speaking of bosses of this DLC, they are challenging. Perhaps somewhat more challenging than most bosses in the base game, though I think it's mostly due to them having 3 and at times even 4 actions per turn. So new strategies are required to approach them. But if you've found the base game very hard already, you might want to delay going into the Courtyard until you've gotten a hang of the combat.

There is only one thing I didn't like about this DLC, and that is the invitations mechanic. The thing about boss Courtyard levels is that you cannot just take a party there. You require an invitation item, and each visit into those giant levels will consume 1 invitation. However, the invitations-carrying enemies do not start appearing until the infestation in other dungeons reaches High, and that takes at least 10 or so in-game weeks. To me that just feels like a pointless padding that forces you to wait for no reason. I would've rather preferred to be able to go into the Courtyard levels at any time, because waiting around doesn't really add any challenge and is only there to waste your time.

Lastly, The Flagellant class is a rather interesting one, though a little hard to get a hang of at first as it's quite different to most other hero classes. The Districts buildings each provide small passive bonuses to specific hero classes once built, though each one requires a tonne of heirlooms, so you might find it a little grindy if you wish to build those.

Overall, this is a solid DLC. If you enjoyed the base game and you found its difficulty just right and want something new, then you should enjoy Crimson Court as well. In some ways it is harder than the base game, but with new things it offers, you have more ways of dealing with the challenges, not only the new ones, but also the old ones.

"I'm a Darkest Dungeon veteran. Start a new game, this should be easy!"

End of first quest to courtyard: 2 hero's with crimson curse, other 2 at deaths door, everyone insane.

5 weeks later strongest hero dies while desperately searching dungeon for The Blood.

"... Remind yourself that overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer."

This DLC is simultaneously the best and worst thing to happen to Darkest Dungeon. 

Let's start with the positives:
-The new hero is fantastic. Very balanced, and isn't overshadowed by any other heroes.
-The new trinkets, even though you have to go to the Courtyard to get them, are also fantastic. They are well worth your time (unlike the Courtyard).
-The new enemy and map art is beautiful. It's a shame you have to venture into the Courtyard to see this wonderful art though.
-I personally like the new traveling boss. We've never seen anything like that before in this game, aside from the Collector, so it's a nice touch. (He is very difficult to kill though)
-Districts are alright. They are very expensive permanent bonuses to both heroes and your hamlet, which are in no way necessary but are nice to have nonetheless.

Now for the negatives:
-The Courtyard is the absolute worst thing in existance. In the second mission alone there are over FIFTY rooms to explore; most of which have absolutely nothing in them. And once you find the place you are supposed to go to, it is locked. So you have to backtrack through countless halways (which stress your heroes out while you walk through them) to find a key which may or may not even fit the door. It is like an eternal labyrinth of suffering and torture, with the only reward being trinkets that you won't get to keep anyway because your units will all collapse of heart attakcs before you can retreat (you cannot camp in the Courtyard, even though it is the largest dungeon to date).

-EDIT: Due to the recent drop rate increase for the Blood, managing the Curse has now become astronomically easier. You should have no problem getting The Blood. 

-The difficulty spike is also flabergasting. A level 3 Courtyard quest is the equivalent of a level 5 regular quest. DO NOT bring ANYONE low level to the Courtyard. They will die, and it will be your fault. 

-The "Infection" mechanic is also infuriating. Each regular dungeon run you do after entering the Courtyard increases your chances of running into Courtyard enemies in future runs . Essentially, you don't even have to enter the Courtyard to get infected. The infection follows you wherever you go. It is inescapable. It is everywhere. 

I would highly reccomend that if you purchase the DLC you not enable the Courtyard. Just enjoy the new class and the Districts. If Red Hook decides to fix the Courtyard sometime in the future, my mind may change. But for now, I'd give the DLC a solid 6/10 because of how dreadful the Courtyard is.

Do I recommend this DLC? Yes. 
Do I recommend it on the first playthrough? [b]Absolutely not![/b]


[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+The new character: the Flagellant, is a strong addition to the roster and can be enabled independently of the Crimson Court once bought. If you’re going to get this at some point just buy it now and wait till another play through to enable the Court so you can play with the Flagellant, he’s been nerfed but is still useful as a powerful stress healer, damage sponge, and damage over time dealer.

+ New area with new enemies, music, bosses, and game mechanics.

+ The new enemies are great because they are very thematic and have very specific move sets making each feel very unique to fight, not just damage numbers. You can manipulate them once you know how they function which rewards your knowledge of your enemies.

+ Art style is awesome, as per usual.

+ The trinket sets for each character which you can only get from the new area stretch from mediocre to absolutely necessary, with tantalizing additional hints to the lore of each character.

+ The new ‘epic’ quest mechanic is interesting, instead of a randomly generated dungeon you have to explore a persistent dungeon over several expeditions. But this also has drawbacks…

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The epic quests to the Courtyard encourage a very specific type of playstyle, i.e. heroes that are self sufficient. You can’t bring firewood to camp for stress healing or buffs, so you need to rely on heroes that can go as long as possible without rest. While this isn’t inherently a bad thing it takes away so much choice about which party members to bring and which tactics to use. Each of the Courtyard dungeons is so long you’ll need maybe a half a dozen expeditions so you’ll just be slogging around with the same party again and again. But that’s not all!...

- You need invitations to enter the Courtyard epic dungeon, i.e. you have a limited number of times you can try your luck at the dungeon before you will run out and need to do something else. This isn’t too bad if you know how to cheese the system using the right combo of heroes and fasting seals so you don’t need food and can keep your party going forever. But that just leads back to the previous con with stagnant party composition. Boring! But this gets FAR worse at the highest level where you NEED stop the expeditions frequently due to the massive amount of abuse heaped on you by the high level enemies. I just got fed up and installed a mod to disable the need for invitations.

- The titular Crimson Curse, the disease any enemy from the Courtyard can inflict, sucks. And I don’t mean that it’s debilitating, it actually has both strengths and weaknesses, but that it acts like an Affliction and can randomly cause your character to do things. I HATE it when my party members refuse to listen to me and get themselves killed. That is why I try so ardently to avoid Afflictions. The problem is, you can’t avoid the Crimson Curse, every single hero that goes there will be by a large majority infected. If you ignore the Courtyard eventually the enemies there start showing up everywhere else infecting you anyway. So, you just have to angrily live with it. I’ve rage quit over a hero who is near death and refuses to heal or be healed and dies because of it! What was I supposed to do!?

- All of the bosses were a let down. While the long treck to each makes the encounter build up a large amount of tension half of the worry was that you weren’t going to make the marathon required to get to them, or if you did that you wouldn’t have the right party members to take them on, not due to the boss itself. The fact that you only get to fight each once is a further let down as you don’t get time to build a repertoire with them like the others. Even further….

- All of the bosses trophies weren’t worth the time to get them. I never used a single one of them even once. Compared to the trophies you get from the vanilla bosses the items the Court bosses give you are terribly mediocre, mostly centering on the Crimson Curse which I also hate.

- And now, the thing I find the most detestable, the reason I recommend you not enable this DLC in your first playthrough: [b]The Difficulty. [/b]

The first 2 epic dungeons weren’t that bad but the final level 6 dungeon was a nightmarish meatgrinder, I would take fully maxed out heroes there with trinkets and a party composition that could make short work of even long level 5 dungeons and have to abandon the mission a few rooms later with a party that was nearly dead. It was devastating… BUT WAIT! That’s not why I am angry, I kept going in the face of adversity, I found the right party composition, I weathered the storm. I became so good the Countess herself, the final boss of the DLC, was a disappointment to me. 

The real point and what’s really unforgivable is that [b]the level 6 crimson court is harder than the Darkest Dungeon itself.[/b] I was so afraid after what I experienced in the Courtyard that the Darkest Dungeon was a letdown. I came close to dying only once in all of the Darkest Dungeon quests, and that once only because I had a bad party composition for the type of quest I was running. It was still shocking and surprising, but it didn’t have anywhere near the impact it should have had as the crowning jewel of the game and it is because of this DLC.  


That is why I think it’s only a good addition on a second+ playthrough, so you definitely, absolutely, should NOT enable this DLC your first time through.

My advice to anyone on the fence on buying this DLC is if you haven't finished the game yet or are near the beginning of the game, you should wait til you've beaten the game or have played the game for a long time. The DLC will make things harder, but that's what Darkest Dungeon is all about: making ridiculously hard scenarios you have to deal with. Hope this helps anyone on their impulse buying spree or their curiosity in buying the DLCs.

The DLC adds a new area, about a dozen new enemies, and a handful of new bosses. While it appears to be a meager addition for an expansion, it does breathe some new life into the game. Ive played over 100 hours of DD, and its one of my favorite games, so this DLC was a welcome addition. Its not as great as I expected and hoped, but that doesnt mean it isnt worth getting. It adds an interesting new mechanic, the crimson curse, which is a new disease. 

The only thing is it cant be cured, and adds MAJOR debuffs to your characters. Its a peculiar feature, Im not quite sure why they added it in. It adds some flavor to the game lore, but other than that its been quite annoying. Your characters basically become strung out on blood and CONSTANTLY need to consume blood vials which are dropped from enemies, or else they get an even larger debuff slapped on. This means that yet another precious inventory slot will need to be spent on bringing blood with you on every single outing. Making matters worse is unlike other diseases, the crimson curse is guaranteed. Basically if you get hit once by a certain enemy (which happens to be the most common one encountered) that character will be infected with the incurable affliction. It will be mostly impossible for you to avoid it, and any hero you send into the court area WILL be infected. This ended up exiling my top heroes, who are now relocated exclusively to the court area, since they already have the disease and I dont want the perma debuffs on all of my heroes.

This review is going to be largely in response to the highly upvoted reviews all panning the dlc for being too hard, basically, i find this humourous considering this is darkest dungeon, but that's not my main issue, my main issue is that many of these reviews omit quite a bit of useful information when it comes to the crimson curse, and the courtyard missions, and The Blood, which i will outline in this review.

First of all, i would like to say that this DLC is not reccommended for first time players, and is absolutely designed with veterans in mind, you will have a bad time if the court is your first DD experience, because it will cut you down mercilessly.

Overall, i highly reccommaned the DLC if you have already played a reasonable amount of the game, understand hero synergies, compositions, trinkets, and other mechanics that often lead to a good chance of success.

[h1] The Crimson Curse! [/h1]

The crimson curse is a special disease introduced in the DLC, it is pretty debilitating, not because of it's stat minuses, as they are actually very minor, something that many reviewers fail to recognise (minus 10% hp, minus 5% to stun, blight and bleed) and, also omitted of course, is that the curse gives a bonus to speed, one of the most important stats in the game if you know what you're doing.

This is inflicted by most courtyard enemies, getting hit by a specific attack by them (the thirst) there is a chance you can get a disease, and the curse can be resisted by disease resist like normal diseases, so if you're very afraid, you can make sure that's high on your heroes to reduce the chances even further.

the disease gets worse, however, going through three stages, passive, craving and wasting. if a hero is passive, he has those minor debuffs, craving, the debuffs becoming a little more severe, except the hp loss, and the speed actually [i]increases[/i]. unfortunately, in craving, the character can do some minor, but predictable "random effects", like being afflicted but much more manageable. these include minor stressing of party (around +7 instead of the normal +10/+15 of afflictions) and are infrequent, another effect is the hero moving forward in the party a single space.

when a character is wasting however, this is when things get scary, the character can die if not given blood, and the curse debuffs are severe, however taking the time to gather blood and use it smartly and scarcely can lead to a fine amount as well as making sure to keep it wherever you find it.

another issue with the curse, however, is that when the infestation gets to medium levels, a Fanatic will show up, and begin hunting your heroes. he has a chance to show up in missions with two or more curse afflicted heroes, and i see a lot of people complaining about this guy.

easy fix, manage your parties so you only have one or two people with the curse going into a normal mission, and save your heavy cursed parties for courtyard missions, i haven't seen him once.

the boss itself is challenging, and terrifying, maybe on the level of a shambler, and not being able to plan for him means he can pop up on you at a bad time and really ruin your run. however if you kill him, you will get some great look, court related trinkets, and even on occasion, [b]an item to cure the curse[/b]

[b]now, the main things that the main reviews on the front page do not mention.[/b]

giving a craving character blood will put them in a fourth state, BLOODLUST. bloodlusted characters get a massive 25% damage buff, big resistance buffs (except bleeding) and a big speed buff. they do have the sort of random effects like craving, except in addition they can randomly heal stress from themselves. this lasts a massvie 22-30 rounds! making one of the BEST BUFFS IN THE GAME.

another thing no one mentions is that the curse is so potant, heroes that have it are IMMUNE TO DISEASES.

suddenly, the curse seems a lot less bad than people have outlined, doesn't it?

[h1]The Courtyard[/h1]

The courtyard is a new zone in the game, and it's quite spooky. A theme of aristocratic parties growing more and more immoral via wine and peer pressure, eventually leading these monsters to become actual monsters via their terrifying thirst for horrific deeds.

The courtyard is tough, and after the first mission you complete court enemies show up in other missions, progressively getting more and more common. so it's recommended you wait until you're well prepared before doing this mission, as people who know this game should be, as it looks like that sort of "special" mission like the darkest dungeon, or a boss (you can tell from the quest rewards, if you've played the game a lot)

however, after this, you are able to go on an "epic" mission, this mission is so long that you are not expected to complete it in a single run, with one party, you are expected to go as far as you can, abandon the quest, and when you try it again your new party will pick up from where the previous one left off, which is a very interesting and awesome mechanic, as a multitude of heroes all work together for the same, massive goal.

access to the epic mission required invitiations, which are dropped by a certain enemy called a gatekeeper in most other missions, in crimson court enemy parties. these generally become very common and after gathering a few you'll find you start discarding them in favour of more loot (again, assuming you know what you're doing with this game.)

the epic quests are a huge labryrinthe of multiple bosses, keys, doors, branching paths, the kind of typical video game dungeon, culminating in an epic and unique boss fight that will greatly challenge you.

an issue with it is that the stress you gain from just being there so long will slowly wear you down, however the dungeon has two types of stress reducing curios that should help mitigate this if you know what you're doing.

[h1] The Flagellant [/h1]

A brief section about this guy.

he is cool, effective, and a pleasure to use. something darkest dungeon has never had which is an excellent feeling is a guy that benefits from taking lots of damage, to such a point where an enemy hits him, with stress or damage, and i'm like "yes! hit him more!" it feels so great.
he can steal bleeds, blights and marks from allies, he can heal a termendous amount by taking lots of damage first, he can even take stress from allies and take it himself.

when the flagellant hits deaths door, everyone in the party is healed, and he gets a big buff while there, risky yes, but very rewarding, especially because the speed boost he gets means he can self heal as soon as it's his turn.

couple this with the fact that he can only be afflicted with one kind, Rapturous, makes him a fairly predictable risk. while rapturous, the flagellant will hurt himself (which is useful) but occasionall hurt others, he also gains big buffs, and minus dodge (again, often helpful with this oddball hero). this makes him a very exciting and fun hero to use, easily one of my favourites now.


All in all it seems that many people who have played this need a simple dose of "git gud" in order to appreciate it, or it could be the case that, since i am playing this a month after release, that many complaints have been changed and i'm getting the updated experience, if so i'm here to correct now out of date information and give my thoughts on my experience so far, which is having sincere difficulty putting it down.

Blah blah blah games supposed to be hard, git gud scrub, blah blah, yeah whatever.

That aside. The flagellant and districts are good and if you want a hard forking map with hard forking enemies then get crimson court.

If you dont want to grind through enemies that invade the rest of the game, make it harder to recover stress, infect everyone constantly with an annoying, all be it very powerful, disease that you cant cure unless you kill a boss, then by all means just uncheck the crimson court part of this dlc and enjoy a very good character and a group of upgrades that you can grind for.

Like seriously just uncheck the crimson court part and keep the other two until you become some leet pro haxor god or decide that you enjoy suffering. You will thank me later.

I really like Darkest Dungeon for the atmosphere and tactics, and I even soldiered on and completed the base game on Darkest difficulty.

I was a bit wary about all of the negative reviews before I bought Crimson Court, but after an adjustment period I found the DLC to really be strikingly good. Even if you dislike the Crimson Court concept, the DLC makes a number of strong gameplay innovations that vastly improve the base game in my opinion. Some, like the district system give the developers a lot of room to expand the feature in the future. Here are some of the reasons Crimson Court is worth your money (in my humble opinion), assuming you dislike the crimson curse system (more on that in a bit) . 

[list]
[*] District system fleshes out the lategame, forces you to make more meaningful decisions regarding heirlooms vs cash, and figuring out district buildorder can be fun. 
[*] Flagellent class is unique and refreshing. Both him and the districts can be turned on while keeping the more contraversial features turned off. Arguably worth buying for DD fans for these features alone. While I think that the Flagellent is a bit too strong compared to the characters in the base game, he does give the player more options with team comps. 
[*] Crimson Court Trinkets add more flavour and more options for the heroes. Getting a clutch set early (like the antiquarian's, which turn her into a reliable off-healer) can change the course of a playthrough. Most of these tend to be a bit too weak compared to generic trinkets in my opinion, but they are fun regardless and usually somewhat powerful early in the game. Enhance the game's replay value. 
[*] A serious challenge for players who are already good at what DD offers. The Crimson court is, as many other have pointed out, very difficult. New boss fights are genuinely gripping and scary, unlike many of the regular bosses. 
[*] The Fanatic allows for more emergent gameplay. He'll derail your runs and force you to adapt. Probably a bit too hard as he has the potential to kick the player while she/he's down. This mixes up the grindier aspects of the game, and adds more variety to your campaign. If you're like me, you may only run into him once in a campaign. 
[*] Epic quests have a lot of potential for future expansions and beating them feels satisfying. 
[list]


So now lets talk about that part of the DLC that has made people most ornery. The Crimson Curse system adds a lot of good things to the way you'll play Darkest Dungeon. It's still a highly flawed system, but not as apocalypic as some users suggest. The Crimson Curse disease that your heroes can contract is a veritable annoyance. The penalties it imparts are interesting in that they forced me to rush towards Crimson Court bosses that I would have taken my time with in vanilla (beating these bosses cures your roster of the curse).This made for more interesting and challenging fights than I was used to. In general, DD is best when the player is uncomfortable and playing by the edge of their seat, which CC helps deliver.  


The Blood management is also interesting in that it provides a real loss condition to campaigns that get caught with dwindling supplies. I like being unsure of when or if I should build a Sangine Vintners district just to control the blood problem. I find that the pressure of being rushed by CC makes the game more exciting, though others may disagree with this preference. 


tldr; Crimson Court adds a lot of solid gameplay improvements that have been overlooked due to the Crimson Curse. Worth your money, but new players should keep the Courtyard feature turned off until they have a firm grasp of the game's mechanics.

To keep the review simple, I will point out three important things that make this DLC not worth the purchase nor worth the play: (Played around 20 hours of the DLC, 200 hours of the base game)

> First, I will comment, the Flagellant class is amazingly designed, if you can catch the game on sale, just buy it for the hero and various features that the DLC provides (Districts). Then just turn off the DLC's map content!

> The base game is incredibly crafted. The game is punishing and fair when you learn its mechanics.
