TL:DR - The Crimson Court is essentially playing Darkest Dungeon with additional minor handicap of The Crimson Curse, which is fun once you learn how to manage it. Expect a learning curve similar to learning how to manage stress for the first time. New bosses and area are cool, they also added new buildings that can be contrusted and trinket pairs that become more powerful when combined as well as a new hero class that's a lot of fun to play. 

Thus far, I'm enjoying the DLC quite a bit. Before I get into the review: [u]Anyone who is having difficulties and/or frustrations with the DLC, feel free to message me for advice on how to manipulate some of the mechanics into your favor.[/u]

A few weeks after beginning a new game, you will receive your first "Invitation" which is an item that allows you to visit the new area called "The Courtyard". You begin with a tutorial introduction dungeon that is tough as nails on its own and will punish you [spoiler]if you're fool enough to enter with weak, under-leveled and under-upgraded characters[/spoiler]. A new enemy-type called "Bloodsucker" inhabit this land who will honor you in battle by spreading the aforementioned curse. In addition, you must also get used to handling slight alterations to how torchlight works [spoiler](a torch gives your party a 1 Battle buff, while the regular torchlight always stays in a constant state that with it's own buffs and de-buffs)[/spoiler] as well as new curios, traps and obstacles. 

After finishing the first courtyard mission, these new bloodsuckers will [spoiler]begin to spawn in surrounding dungeons[/spoiler]. Not only that, but they will quickly spread of the Crimson Curse to your heroes, which is a disease that cannot be cured in the Sanitarium and must be managed in addition of everything else you have to manage on an average quest (provisions, inventory space, health, stress,  trinkets, ratio of treasures to heirlooms... ect). This becomes an extra step you have to take to survive, including collecting a vials of what's called "The Blood" which works as a medicine for the curse. The Blood is found as random loot, most commonly after Bloodsucker battles. 

The Curse itself has several different stages, each one worse than the previous. Only feeding your cursed heros the blood will give them their strength back and keep them from shriveling up and dying on you. The curse acts as both a disese and an affliction by way of giving a slight but ever-present debuff (as well as a small speed buff) and in most of its stages the curse will sometimes force undesirable actions from your heroes, similar but les devestating than an affliction. 

As the Crimson Curse spreads among your heroes, the only way to cure yourself of it is to adventure into The Courtyard and kill one of inhabiting three new bosses. The catch is that these areas are unlike anything you've had to deal with up until now. The Courtyard dungeon size are of, what they call, "Epic" length, which can feature up to [spoiler]100 rooms with gates that require a certain colored key[/spoiler] , and minibosses to mess you up along the way. Also, the game does not provide you with firewood so you cannot camp unless you [spoiler] find firewood from one of the curios[/spoiler]. As such, bringing a party that can heal itself well, both HP and Stress is vital. 

[spoiler]The catch is that once you leave this area, you begin again in the same point on the map and when you abandon the quest. The map is not proceedurely generated either, meaning that it can be learned and mastered just like the Darkest Dungeon areas.[/spoiler]

In addition to all this madness is another boss called The Fanatic. He is a [spoiler]wandering[/spoiler] boss who is there to hunt heros afflicted with the crimson curse. The loading screen will change to a picture of him, warning you that you will have to face him at some point in the dungeon, and he is [/spoiler]no joke of a fight. I was absolutely wrecked the first time I faced him, losing two heroes and having another a death's door and one on death's doorstep. 

Helping you along the way is a new class of hero named The Flagellant. He's a frontline hero with attacks that inflict heavy bleed buildup and has interesting mechanics that buff him when he's close to death, with a powerful but situational-only healing ability as well as an ability that transfers marks, bleeds and blights from another hero onto himself. [spoiler]A party of a Vestal --> Jester --> Houndmaster/Highwayman --> Flagellant makes running around in the epic sized courtyard missions almost trivial once you know what you're up against. [/spoiler]

Also here to help you are the new trinkets sets. Each hero class has a new pair of trinkets that when equipped together give an even larger boost. For example, if you equip both of the Highwayman's new trinkets, in addition to the individual boosts from each trinket, it'll also give you a +45% virtue chance. 

Lastly, there is a new area of the Hamlet called "The District". The district has areas for buildings to be constructed that provide powerful buffs, but it requires A LOT of upgrade heirlooms a the new "Blueprint" item, which is earned by defeating Veteran or stronger bosses in addition to the one the game provides you early on. Constructing a "Bank" will give you an additional 5% gold on whatever money is in the hamlet when you depart for a mission. If you plan ahead and know what you want to build, it can make parts of the game much easier to compensate for the additional hardships the curse will bring you. [spoiler]Also, I noticed that with districts enabled, heirlooms seemed to drop at a larger rate.[/spoiler] 

All-in-all, I recommend the DLC to anyone wanting another layer of difficulty added into an already harsh and unforgiving game. I have read many, many negative reviews and many of the complaints reminded me of back when Darkest Dungeon first added corpses to the game. Lots of people complained because their old tactics needed adjusting and didn't fancy going through an initially painful re-learning phase. I've always found Darkest Dungeon to be best as a stressful but rewarding game the first playthrough and then a fun challenge once understood. The Courtyard, bosses, crimson curse, flagellant and districts have been a welcome addition and I can't wait for see what kinds of masochistic wonders Red Hook will bestow upon us next.

While having some excellent ideas, the Crimson Court unfortunately turns the grind in The Darkest Dungeon up to 11 without making the extra time spent consummately interesting.

  The best part of the new mission is the flagellent class.  It's possibly a little too strong when not in a dungeon full of bleed resistent enemies, but he's thematically cool and fun to play.  

  The rest is mostly bad.  The DLC adds vampirism, which somewhat unavoidably will spread among your crew and put them in a state where they require regular infusions of a blood loot drop to keep going, even when not questing.  The game pressures you to start the DLC plotline by immosing town-wide stress reduction penalties until you kick off the quest chain, and then starts spawning vampiric enemies in every mission with increasing frequency if you don't clear the quest chain bosses in a timely fashion.

  The vampirism itself isn't quite as scary as it might first seem.  Passive blood drops alone will keep alive several heroes who you aren't adventuring with regularly, without requiring you to run the mission that lets you grind for blood.  In fact, when you first get someone you care about infected you might be tempted to run on the blood cellar quest to get some blood as a buffer against losing them, but this is a trap: you don't need to, and running the mission with a mostly non-vampiric party will just leave you stuck with more vampires to feed.

  After some initial fear that I was going to lose my infected star heroes because they happened to get hit by a bite attack, I started to like The Crimson Court.  The blood mechanic is more bark than bite, and nicely adds an atmosphere of stress and doom to the game.  Then, however, I started discovering the epic dungeons and how the vampirism impacts the economy.

  The epic dungeons themselves are the worst.  They're required to reset the progress of the vampire plague and eventually reduce it to the status of a normal disease.  However, they're a giant maze that you're expected to complete across multiple sessions and start at veteran level so you need to send in skilled heroes to progress- and fairly tough, as well.  So, you send in a bunch of skilled troops and play until you're chewed up, quit and suffer additional negative traits and stress for "losing", and don't get a completion reward so you're forced to grind money to get them back up into fighting state again.  Grind the dungeon, grind for coins to recover, repeat.  Darkest Dungeon is designed around attrition and tough financial decisions, but this is painful and pointless.

  Compounding this is the way the vampire plague impacts with the low level economy.  When things get rough in Darkest Dungeon, you may find yourself in the position of taking a bunch of free heroes off the stagecoach and running an easy mission for money.  That's an essential part of the game- it both trains up a back roster of heroes to help you replace unfortunate losses in the higher ranks of your roster, and acts as a path to recovery when things go bad.

  Vampirism partially breaks this.  You can still do it, but instead of just as a recovery mechanic or roster-building mechanic you'll probably find yourself doing it just to grind gold to fund your anti-vampirism crusade, which is a lot less fun.  Furthermore, these runs become a lot less rewarding on two fronts.  First, the appearance of the vampiric enemies in easy missions can increase the difficulty of the missions somewhat in some environs, meaning you're more likely to fail these missions and get less monetary payoff for your grind.  Secondly, the vampiric minions will infect some of your newbies with vampirism, which means you'll want to keep fewer of them because some of them will start competing with the heroes you care about for blood.  This means you also get less of a roster-building payout as well.

  You'll have to do fresh-off-the-coach runs more frequently, for less enjoyable reasons, and with less payoff for your grind time.

  The you-might-become-a-vampire factor also means more turnover in your mid-tier roster and that you'll be fielding your built-up but infected heroes less to reduce their blood comsumption, but this is at least a mostly manageable onus.

  On top of this there's the wandering vampire-hunter boss, which adds a random difficulty spike to missions and further punishes you for not just sidelining your characters when they get infected.  Both bad ideas, although at least he also can drop a cure which acts as a stabilizing factor against getting stuck with too many vampires in your roster.

  As a final flaw regarding Vampirism, just a matter of bad UI design rather than mechanical issues, the Provisions screen doesn't warn you if you're about to enter a dungeon with vampiric characters and no blood to feed them.  Expect to enter a dungeon and immediately realized that your run's a bust because you've got a lot of starving and heavily penalized vampires, and the game's already autosaved behind you.  This is inexcusable.

  Vampirism just doesn't work for Darkest Dungeon as implemented.  The Epic Dungeon idea needs to be abandoned entirely.  For Vampirism in general to work, it needs to be excluded from starter missions, which would probably mean reworking the tiers so that you had four or five semi-overlapping mission tiers where the first tier was renown 0-1 and had 
no vampiric enemies.   As it is, the variety provided by the new location and enemies, plus the small amount of additional strategic depth added are absolutely not worth the amount of repetion and grind they add.

  The Crimson Court also adds "districts" which are a big estate material sink to get persistent bonuses, which seems like it would be a fine addition as a handout to let players struggling with the game eventually grind past it to beat it but doesn't seem like it has much of a place in the game otherwise.

  Overall, The Crimson Court has some neat ideas but makes you spend a lot of time treading water for little additional fun.  I would not recommend it.

This is the Crimson Court's most notable feature: A brand new permanent debuff that can't be cured in the Sanatorium and will eventually kill the afflected hero unless their addiction for an item called "The Blood" is constantly met. Seems oppressive, but that's the general atmosphere of the Darkest Dungeon already so I'm not sure what I expected.

How "fun" this is depends on a number of factors: Does the Curse have any strategic benefit (is it strictly a negative), how easy is it to get the Curse, and how easy is it to get "The Blood" to prevent your heroes from dying?

The answer is mostly not, very, and not very.

Even if you choose to ignore the Crimson Court the enemies in that zone that cause The Curse will start to show up in increasing numbers in other zones. Eventually you will get the Curse. The hero will need an item called "The Blood" to prevent the from dying, and they'll need it every 3-4 weeks. If you have a roster of 10 people that get Cursed that's about 3 Bloods every week.

Blood is a random loot pickup and in standard dungeons is not plentiful. Thankfully there are dedicated Blood run missions in the Court which can help stock your inventory, but inventory management was already a pain before the Crimson Court and this only makes it worse.

With that out of the way we can discuss the rest of the content. It's mostly good. Instead of Medium sized dungeons the Crimson Court levels are all massive and non-randomized. They actually take multiple entries to explore. This is going to be up to personal preference, but I found it a bit exhausting. Long dungeons already were troublesome since you can't bring back all the loot you'd like, and sadly inventory management or space has not been changed at all. I found myself having to leave the dungeon not because my heroes were too stresses, but because my bags were full.

By far the best feature of the Crimson Court is the best part of Darkest Dungeon in general: Art design. The monsters are all fallen dilettantes and aristocrats that have mutated into bloodsucking parasites and insects, and are barely able to disguise their previous human forms. The metaphor is obvious and brilliant all at the same time. I've never seen a grotesque beetle wear a powdered wig before and it's awesome to behold.

There are some trinkets, which are mostly bad. But the new class The Flagellant, has a unique playstyle that's somehow different from the other 16. He is a lot of fun to use despite being nerfed in the last patch.

So we have a mixed bag. I still think there's enough content here to be worth getting. The Curse is not a fun mechanic (and there's no escaping it), inventory management is even worse now, but the new class and monsters are very good.

So for anyone wondering if they should buy this now that DD2 is in early access and others might be wanting to jump into DD1 for the first time. The crimson curse is easy to manage if you pay attention and has upsides and downsides as with anything else so curing it isn't necessarily the thing you always want to do, Of course it can kill heroes but so can everyone else. I cannot recommend this DLC in the current state.

The Crimson Curse mechanic is straight bad and the worst kind of video game artificial difficulty increase, there's really no way around this. It weakens your characters to literally no appreciable gain, can kill characters (there is a 0% chance they don't add a difficulty toggle for this later, so why isn't it there at release?), and worst of all can cost you control of your characters. Anyway, this may be too hard for a first playthrough, but I made it just fine despite the inconveniences.

Three major things are added : the Courtyard, the Flagellant, and Districts. You can toggle each of them on and off, so I'd still very much recommend buying it and just toggling the Courtyard (so the part that causes the problems that resulted in all these negative reviews) and activating the others.

Because this DLC may add very nasty stuff that made a lot of people angry, but it also adds a lot of OP stuff to make up for it, which you see mentioned a lot less strangely enough. All in all, I see it as a "bad" design decision that I'm glad they've made, using Tyler Sigman's words, co-funder of Red Hook himself.

The Flagellant is a new class. He's also my favorite. He's also broken as shit. Sure, bringing a Flagellant along won't make any dungeon a cakewalk, but he is one goddamn strong addition to your party, and shines everywhere except the ruins. Basically, he makes things bleed a LOT, and if he goes below 50% HP he has the choice between either healing 50% of his HP (at max level, 33% at lowest) and inflicting massive bleed damage upon one enemy, or healing both himself and one teammate 50% (or 33 at lowest, again) of their HP. Add above average stats to the mix and a lot of other powerful stuff and you end up with a dude capable of clearing dungeons and bosses by himself. (Yeah. Look it up)

The Districts are basically endgame, huge bonuses you can buy with artifacts and a bit of gold. Most notably, the Bank, which is not that expensive and basically gives you 5% of your total money each week. You may not realize how well this can snowball, but you'll end up with hundreds of thousands of gold really fast, if not millions. It essentially removes gold farming from the game. Thaaaat's pretty strong.

That's the OP stuff. Now for the star of the show, the Courtyard.
As early as Week 10 or so, you'll be asked to visit the Courtyard. If you refuse, you'll suffer from reduced stress healing in town (and no town events) as long as you don't visit it, and if you do, you'll trigger the **Crimson Curse**, which has caused many tears and many ragequits. 
Courtyard missions, other than the very first, simpler one, are exceptionally long dungeons with a boss at the end, which you are expected to do in several tries, since you restart them from where you stopped during the last one. The new enemies and bosses are absolutely amazing, the third boss in particular blew my mind by how amazing her design was. However, the enemies, bosses and missions themselves are really tough, and are not to be taken lightly.
But the real nasty part isn't the missions, it's the **Crimson Curse**. Basically, Courtyard enemies have a small chance to give you the **Crimson Curse**, which gives minor debuffs and acts as a lesser affliction when the hero is either craving blood, or in blood-lust state. For every so often (usually once or twice per dungeon in a medium one), your hero will crave blood, a new resource you can find scattered around. Giving it to them will give them slight buffs and cause you to lose control of them sometimes, same thing when they're craving minus the buffs. All in all, it's annoying.
The real kicker is that Courtyard enemies can spawn in *any* dungeon after a while. Even worse, they can replace so many of the local enemies your fights will be 50% (or more) Courtyard enemies sometimes, while you'd expect the Warrens to have, you know, PIG DUDES. And they can give you the Crimson Curse. So yeaaaah, you end up having a good chunk of your roster with a permanent lesser affliction.
Although all your roster is cured as soon as you beat a Crimson Court boss, and the **Crimson Curse** becomes a curable disease when you beat the final Courtyard boss.
So you have a DLC that forces itself upon you, changes the whole game around, and gives everyone annoying permanent afflictions.

It's amazing. Best purchase in a while. Just deactivate the Courtyard if you don't feel up to it. Hell, I activated it during my first playthrough, and I did fine, so it's not as bad as people make it out to be. Just buy it.

I liked everything about this DLC until about week 25, where the crimson curse mechanic becomes unbearable. When a hero is cursed, they have to consume blood, which is a random drop (and hence you can run out if you get unlucky), or they eventually die. Further, the hero loses 10% max hp, a bunch of resists, and will randomly pass their turn, cause party-wide stress damage, or attack friendlies. This is permanent. 

The new enemies inflict this permanent, crippling debuff at a ridiculous rate. You can expect to get cursed every 2 or 3 encounters with the new enemies,  which are not restricted to the new area, but appear in every other area. An expedition to the new area will surely curse your entire party. The encounters seem designed to guarantee that you will be cursed: level 1 encounters are typically two stun-immune enemies with too much hp to consistently one-shot and two enemies with 11 speed. 

If you go into an expedition with 4 cursed characters, there is a 99% chance of an extremely difficult encounter boss, named the Fanatic, spawning. I'm at a point where it feels like I simply can't put together a party that can both clear an expedition and kill the Fanatic, while my dwindling supply of blood means that very soon my cursed heroes will simply start dying off. And there's nothing I can do about it! There is no counterplay to avoid being cursed in the first place, and no strategy to obtain blood reliably if you are running out. 

This is supposed to be a game that's about preparation, but you are utterly helpless to deal with the curse. It's simply not fun.

Update:
I received quite a bit of negative feedback over this review, and after several balancing patches came out, I tried this DLC again. 

In spite of multiple patches increasing the drop rate of blood, and dismissing lower-level heroes with the curse, I lost a level 4 hero to the curse and now have two more level 4 heroes in the "wasting" state (they will automatically die if left in town, and have a random chance to instantly die if you take them on an expedition) and no blood remaining. I counted, and my last SEVEN encounters with bloodsuckers dropped zero blood. 

When your hero dies from the curse, there's no death's door check, or any other mitigating mechanic, unless you risk bringing them on the expedition with you. Of course, if they hit a blood check, which occur randomly and without warning, they will die on the expedition and then I face the standard problems of being on an expedition with two dead characters. This DLC is not for everyone. You either love it or hate it and if you love it you probably still hate it at times. It gives you a lot more to manage and can cause things to spiral out of control very easily. You have to balance the court with the rest of the game and playing on Stygian mode can amplify this a lot, though beating the court is not required to end Stygian Mode's timer.

As for the vampirism itself, it is both a buff at times and a major debuff for the rest. But as long as you're careful and you keep blood on hand it is doable for the most part. The wandering boss though... Ohhh boy he's tough. You always need to be prepared for him to show up in a mission.

The crimson court dungeons themselves are very interesting. The mechanics are ENTIRELY different. They're huge and can take multiple dives to actually clear. It can be worth it to take a team in for clearing and then leave, get another invite via the base game, and take in a boss killing team.

It's not for everyone but it can be a great challenge to cut one's teeth on.

I wish I could recommend the Crimson Court DLC, because I love all its parts.

I love the new enemies. The Crimson Curse is a unique and dreadful take on a very, very old myth - the vampire. The court itself has beautiful and terrifying backgrounds, curios, and designs. Incorporating the court into a normal game creates an interesting challenge. The new champion type is very fitting for the setting, and has interesting skills and abilities. The new boss fights and enemies are well-designed, challenging, and range from bothersome to frightening.

So why don't I like this expansion?

The whole, in this instance, is much less than the sum of its parts, and it mostly comes down to level design. In order to defeat the challenges of the Crimson Court, one must venture into the court and defeat its boss monsters. Sound familiar? It should. That's the same formula for the rest of the game, one that works. But they made a huge mistake.

Firstly, the bosses are in defined maps that never change, and they are very, very large, sprawling maps. They make the DD3 mission look rather small in comparison. Unfortunately, there's also no firewood given to you for any of these maps - while it's possible to loot some, that's never enough to get through the whole map in one go-through. The progress of each party is saved though, so it seems at least that part was anticipated. Unfortunately, that's not enough.

Each of these maps will take multiple attempts to clear. So the first few ventures, perhaps event the first eight or ten ventures in the larger maps, they will all fail. That means no resolve XP is awarded for them. They're very high-level maps (almost universally intended for max level heroes) so you're risking your high-level heroes for no reward. In addition, if you run out of high level heroes (very possible due to the very lethal nature of the court and its bosses), you'll have to level up more of them outside of the court. The new updates to the coach help, but you can never throw fresh heroes into these missions and hope to accomplish anything. So the new missions suck up all your resources and drain you dry, giving precious little in return.

What's even worse, they are very large and have locked doors with color-coded keys. So you spend a lot of your time simply walking from one end of the map to the other. Have I mentioned they're huge maps? They're huge, with tons and tons of dead space. Be prepared to spend a large amount of time just walking into dead space with nothing actually happening.

I was very disappointed, because everything else about the DLC was great. If they had just made the Court a regular dungeon like the Cove or the Weald, I'd have happily recommended it to you.

After having played DD's original campaign, I was eager to start a new campain with Crimson Curse installed. After all, any dark dungeon worthy of that name has to have bloodsucking creatures.

The design of the “vampires” is interesting: not your standard vampires and certainly not vampires that sparkle in the sun but more like parasites. You will face mosquitos and ticks and hybrids between these and humans which are dressed like 17th century nobles. Everytime these creatures bite your heroes, there is a chance that they become infected with the crimson curse and that means that they will start craving blood.

And so, you will have to gather the blood by either completing a gathering mission, finding the blood as loot or building a new district in your hamlet. 

The new districts are something to look forward to as they do add extra benefits e.g. the bank adds a 5% interest on stored gold every week. However, they are expensive and will require a lot of money and deeds/crests in order to be built. Also, you will need blueprints which will only drop from either the CC bosses or the vanilla bosses at higher levels so, no blueprints from low level bosses. One blueprint will be given for free as a town event. This will result in most of the new buildings to be built only later on once you have a more gold and higher level heroes.

Personally, I believe that these new building are not essential; I only built the vinters building for the extra blood production and the bank.

The new mechanic brought by having afflicted heroes can be tedious: you will have to manage your blood which, luckily enough, is rather easy to get but, should you have too many heroes with the curse, it will become a game of balancing normal quests and gathering blood quests. 

Which brings me to the new wandering boss: the fanatic. I like the idea of having a wandering boss actively hunting down your afflicted heroes but, especially at the beginning, this boss can be very hard to defeat and it can be frustrating to lose a party member due to a boss that can feel overpowered. However, like any other boss in DD, it's easy once you know how.

The new dungeon i.e. The Courtyard is both good and bad. It's a huge place and it is not meant to be explored in one go. The positive side is that you can leave at any time and you can restart from where you left but, as a negative, there are quite a few hard encounters which can wreck your day if you just charge in.

I did find it tedious at times to simply go in to explore and map out the whole level also considering that, in order to enter, you will need “invitations” which will only drop from the new enemies that you will encounter in the original dungeons and this is what annoyed me the most as, every time you enter the courtyard, you will use one invitation, even if you do not kill the boss. But, so far, I've managed to find quite a few of those but I do not like the idea of limiting access to a dungeon, considering also its size.

The new class, the flagellant, is good and can feel more powerful than the other classes when dealing with enemies that bleed and you will have access to him fairly soon. Some of his abilities seem to be too good but, considering the new difficulty spikes, it's a fair trade off.

So, is it bad? Is it good? As per DD, it is not for everyone and some of the mechanics can be annoying but overall it is a good DLC that will hopefully, sate your thirst for blood.

Don't be put off by the "Mixed" reviews, this DLC is a fantastic boon to the mid-to-late game of the campaign that keeps the game from feeling stagnant. Having an sort of alternate main quest that you have to choose when to progress in is really fresh, and the new enemies and bosses are all fantastic, with the exception of the very last (but also very optional) boss. Definitely heed the game's warning about enabling it if you're apprehensive about difficulty, but once you've learned the game's systems, all the content this expansion adds is exceptional.

The new dungeons are not random anymore. Wich could be ok i guess, if there were a lotofthem . But there are not and you just get the feeling that there is nothing to explore and somehow it makes the game feel stale.

really doesn't recommend it. It makes the vanilla experience somewhat less enjoyable. If anything buy it after you finished the base game.

I recommend this for the extras, not the campaign. If it were just the campaign, I'd thumb this down so hard, lol.
Flagellant is an ugly version of my boyfriend (at the time of writing), and just so happens to be an extremely fun and versatile class... 10/10
Districts are something to do with all the extra stuff you have, and the effects make things a little "nicer" in such an otherwise cruel and unforgiving game.

Important Edit: You can turn the Crimson Court Campaign, Flagellant Class, and Districts on or off individually at any time. Again reinforcing why this can still get a thumbs up despite the core content.

The campaign itself... well, eh... I'm glad it's not as bad as it was on release, but wow. The campaign constantly screams at you to pay attention to it, or else. If you start a game with the campaign enabled, you'll be swarmed every week with a stress recovery debuff, meaning you're going to have a roster full of increasingly stressed out idiots that you're just not going to be able to quell. It'd be fine if the swarm event started spamming itself when you should be able to start the content, but it happens while your roster is full of 0s and a few 1s.
Believe me, you can't just walk in there with your 0s and 1s, they'll be eaten alive by the lovely Crocodilian you'll see some people crying about (and yes, it really is as unenjoyable to fight as most people make it out to be), so you're going to be seeing "The Town is Abuzz" over and over... and over... and over... for a fair while as you build up a team ready to shut the damn thing up.

But oh, once you go shut the event up, and finally you have some (relative) peace in the Hamlet, now your entire game is infected. Have fun!

One of the very many charms of Darkest Dungeon is how heroes who go crazy, tend to at least have lines suited to their class or role. But the curse...? No, the curse's script is just lazy (no way to sugarcoat this, it is lazy).
The same small set of lines for each and every character... yes, shut the hell up, I've read that line 50 times already - in the current playsession. The Crimson Curse basically possesses your characters with the personality of the exact same teenage vampire edgelord. I can't imagine how frustrating it used to be on release, what with the 1/3 chance of infection creating an army for this one edgy dumbass to speak through, because I was bored of the curse within a couple of hours at most.

Aside from that, it's a welcome change to have some huge dungeons you can come and go from as you please (people complaining about no camping aren't making any sense - being able to go back home renders camping pointless, and even then there's still a way to camp if you experiment with the new curios), and the bosses are interesting.
The Countess is a nightmare and puts the Darkest Dungeon itself to shame, but still beatable.

The enemies are okay and varying degrees of just the right amount of annoying... only complaint is with the Chevalier.
Chevalier should really be a Size 2 with a little more health (his sprites are clearly Size 2, but for some reason they have him clipping horribly with surrounding enemies in a single slot). Oh yeah... those big Chevalier bugs are going to be the main cause for deaths to this content. Have fun!

New trinkets are a mixed bag, and appear to be infamously bad overall according to the community.
The first trinkets I got were the Vial of Sand and Glass Shard, so of course I thought they looked decent at first, but that was just me being lucky and getting two of the only good ones of the lot... then I saw the rest eventually (what the hell is with the Bounty Hunter's and Jester's sets?!).
Oh yeah, and speaking of trinkets? The Boss Trophies are worthless (not hyperbole; they are worthless). Maybe the first will be useful for a little more speed on someone for a few expeditions, but that's it.

If you really love Darkest Dungeon, it's worth trying this mistake of a campaign out on your second playthrough (the game actually warns you it'll ruin your experience if you switch the campaign on in your first run). Then it's up to you if you ever do it again.
People who love the way it infects the game, and gamer masochists, will love it forever and never turn it off (not even temporarily at the start of an estate).

Wish I had read the reviews before jumping on this one... Man this DLC is a real pain. As everyone else has already said, the curse is extremely hard to deal with and very common. Even using the mod that reduces the chance to get the curse I'm still finding I get it way too often. According to the wiki the only way you can get rid of the curse is to get an invitation to and complete a quest in the new Courtyard area (not including the starting quest), which would be fine if it wasn't impossible to get an invitation. Overall the crimson court is a really cool concept. The thematic part of it was really well done and it adds a great deal to the lore with things like vampires and gluttony which fit the game. The flagellant is a great character that really has no equivalent in terms of play style or personality. But they didn't have to make the mechanics of the crimson court so damn annoying. My biggest gripe with the crimson court is not the difficulty but how the game implements the difficulty. This DLC was made for the most hardcore of players that want to play the game for hundreds of hours on end and for those people this is a perfect DLC. It adds a lot of ways for characters to randomly die and will set you back. For those people who have the game completely mapped out it is great. For the casual player it is a nightmare. The wandering boss that it adds is nothing short of the hardest normal boss you can fight, which wouldn't be a problem if it also dropped good items which it does not. It also does not help that it is an unoriginal fight as well. The fight boils down to a much harder hag in almost every way. Turn one grab, turn 2 de-buff, turn 3 hit. rinse and repeat with some variation. It also pokes at the flaw in game design that is speed, with three turns it is almost impossible to use characters that need setup consistently as you will have almost no indication of when the boss is taking its turns. The crimson curse mechanic is also very random. Random chance to get it, random chance to spawn the boss, random chance to die from the curse while wasting, random chance to get bloodsucker enemies in any area of the map. If you have this DLC with the farmsted, the nuances of each zone are now overshadowed by the chance of 3 different random spawns that are completely out of your control bar what you do in the mission select screen. This was the collecter and shamblers job to begin with, but instead of a small chance that they spawn it is almost guaranteed that the crimson curse will make its way into your levels every mission (also don't forget you still have to deal with the two wandering bosses that are already in the game). With this DLC it is not important but crucial that you make multiple teams that will do well in the crimson court at the start of the game or you will feel the consequences of not giving the DLC your full attention. This DLC DEMANDS attention and will completely change how you should go about completing the game. This is why I feel it is terrible to anyone but the most seasoned players of the game. Even on the lower difficulties it punishes players for not acting in certain ways due to a lack of knowledge

In the end, was it fun to say all my characters I liked had aids, yes. Did I like having yet another map with leper supremacy, yes. Do I recommend this DLC to anyone but those who solely play on torchless hardest difficulty, no. If you are anything like me, difficulty alone is not enough for me to like something. I already had issues with things like multiple turns ignoring speed, how the first ~6 of my characters died on the first hit of deaths door and how random chance artificially inflates difficulty. I completely stopped playing torchless after a giant crit 1 shot Reynauld for 83 on full health and lost me the achievement making me restart my 50+ hours of game play. That is how most enemies in this DLC feel, and how most of the mechanics of this DLC work. If you like to gamble, this DLC will give you more dopamine than anything else in the game could, but IMO I don't have the time or care to constantly be punished for things that are out of my control. That happens in real life enough, I don't need it in my games as well.

Don't buy this DLC.

I love Darkest Dungeon (around 200h played and a positive review) but this DLC is garbage.

Now that I've completed the Crimson Court DLC, I figured it was time to give it a review. 

So, the first time you enter the Courtyard level, you trigger an event which causes the Courtyard's enemies to begin appearing on other stages, gradually increasing in frequency over time. Normally, this would be fine, as the enemies have great designs and attacks. They're fairly tough, as they have very high speed and dodge stats, and slightly higher HP than some other standard mooks. The problem with this is in that they can afflict your characters with the Crimson Curse, which is a debuff that causes them to crave a specific item that you get from fighting these enemies and lowers their stats, and it will eventually kill them. I don't mind the enemies always getting to go first, it's an RPG and damage is expected, but nearly guaranteeing a hit eventually and giving my characters a debuff that can't be cured at the sanitarium is not so fun and engaging, especially since you can't even build your team to deal with it. 

But fine, I dealt with it. To cure this debuff, I had to kill the Baron. He wasn't super tough, but the map was obnoxiously long and you got no fire wood. There were locked doors everywhere, and I had to hunt for keys, while being constantly bombarded by these same enemies. This took a long time, it was mostly walking, and I did it in one run despite being able to leave and come back later, because I didn't want to fight more of these enemies just to get another invitation, which I would need to get back to the manor. It was then that I realized that to REALLY get rid of the Crimson Curse for good, I'd need to kill the Countess, because if I don't, the frequency of the Crimson Court enemies would gradually increase over time again. 

This makes things even worse, because that meant that I needed to do TWO MORE of these massive maps, with the last one being the same difficulty as the Darkest Dungeon. This means that for most people, you'd need to grind a max level team just to get rid of this frustrating mechanic. I recommend getting a mod to remove the Crimson Curse or something, because this DLC is pretty silly, aside from the added trinkets and characters.

I Love this game. 200 hours in the base game. +30 hours in the Crimson Court DLC.

Went into the Courtyard early with some level 1 adventurers. Found the Croc, realised what I was in for. Ran away. Came back with level 2 adventurers, skills, gear. Still dangerous but manageable. 

Now for the Baron! The "Epic" length may put people off, but they need to realise that the game saves your position when you leave the Baron's Courtyard. That way you can make repeated excursions clearing separate wings of the Baron's estate until you eventually confront the bloated fiend himself. Sure it is labyrinthine and the keys are hidden. The red key was harder to find for me than the blue and yellow keys. Definitely a brutal dungeon, but great gameplay there. I haven't even started the Viscount yet! The only nitpick I may have is waiting to find random Gatekeepers for Baron's invitations, but I had collected about 6 by week 35.

As for the curse itself, Blood Management is the name of the game. People need to use characters with the curse sparingly and the blood sparingly as well. Collecting some of the new very rare curse related trinkets early on greatly helps with the Blood Management. One trinket is a dead rat that prevents a character with the crimson curse from wasting away within a dungeon.

To repeat, I love this game, this DLC, and Red Hook for putting so much love into it. I hope they continue to make more improvements to this game for years to come!

I really don't enjoy anything this DLC adds, exception being the new class, which is great fun to use.

Middling

~ I do appreciate the variety

~ The Crocodile boss is practically a troll boss, having a low-warning attack that can deal upwards of 20 damage to your entire, Apprentice-Difficulty party, likely immediately bringing most of them to death's door. Bad
- Crimson Curse is potentially the most obnoxious game mechanic I have experienced in a very long time. Incurable, permanent disease that debuffs hero stats significantly no matter what you do, causes stress events constantly, causes your heroes to attack each other constantly, etc. It's basically like permanently being Afflicted with a milder version of every Affliction combined, and then you can get Afflicted on top of it which makes a hero completely nonfunctional. It's so common that 3/4 of your roster will end up infected unless you dismiss heroes with it, which puts a massive strain on your roster and funding anyway. You're even punished for treating it because Bloodlust has a bunch of potentially serious negative effects it also can cause, forcing you to either deal with those or deal with the constant stress bombs from Craving.

- The CC enemies appearing in other regions trashes party comps in a way you can't really account or compensate for. They're all extremely resilient to Blight and Debuffs (and moderately resistant to stuns), greatly weakening those abilities because any given encounter could be replaced with CC enemies. No skills or quirks give bonuses against CC enemies either, as they're a unique type. They also almost all have super high dodge, meaning you need either dodge reduction skills or very high accuracy.

- CC enemies are extremely fast, almost guaranteed to go first, making it even more difficult to avoid getting your entire party infected, and partially nullifying the sense of urgency and depth I mentioned as a good thing because enemies will always go so fast you can't take them out before they become a problem.

- Gatekeepers are so difficult to actually kill before they inflict a free 20+ stress on your entire party and then leave that it's infuriating.

- CC greatly diminishes the usefulness of the Shieldbreaker and Plague Doctor (and somewhat the Grave Robber), as now you can get heavily blight-resistant enemies anywhere. 

The thing that finally pushed me to write this up was that I had an absolutely horrible apprentice-level dungeon venture that was completely caused by CC. Very first encounter was CC enemies, only one path so I can't retreat unless I abandon mission. Gatekeeper goes first with their obscene speed, immediately inflicts 20 stress and wrecks my party order, making me unable to do anything with two of my units. Two mosquitos inflict CC on two of my party members instantly. I kill one of them and Bleed the standing enemy with 20% protection (I'll remember names eventually). I miss a Bleed and Dodge debuff on the Gatekeeper. Gatekeeper goes first on round 2, immediately flees for free 20 stress on whole party and filling the field with more mosquitos. Entire party gets CC'd, Plague Doctor gets hyper-focused to death's door (thankfully doesn't die...), Plague Doctor also Afflicted despite coming in at zero stress.

Second encounter. Leper attacks teammates for 8+ damage two turns in a row, then passes turn on the third turn. Cascade of CC stress events causing my entire party to gain over 30 stress in two turns despite not being hit with any stress attacks. I flee battle and abandon mission before plague doctor has a heart attack and dies. Dismiss entire party because they're all level 0 or 1 and all have CC.

Could I have played this better? Almost certainly, I don't claim to be good at this game. But this still felt like a completely overwhelming combination of events I couldn't have "properly" reacted to, all caused by elements of this DLC that I already didn't like. 

Conclusion

Buy this DLC on discount. You can disable Crimson Curse as a mechanic with mods which makes the rest of the DLC tolerable, or use mods to make CC far less annoying and more feature-rich. If you just want the Flagellant and/or Districts you can also do that. Do NOT use the full package for a first playthrough, only use Flagellant and Districts if anything. I'd recommend doing your second run on standard difficulty, and then drop back down to easy for your first run with this DLC if you do intend to use the entire thing.

I'll start by saying I like the Crimson Court expansion, but I also absolutely understand why the reviews are heavily mixed since my own feelings are too.

The general idea behind it is solid - a vampiric curse your characters can catch, and which needs to be managed or it can spiral out of control. In my opinion dealing with it isn't as difficult as others have made it out to be, and I personally find it a fun additional bit of management. However it's not without its flaws.

The curse has multiple states depending on how "hungry" the character is for Blood, the new consumable for controlling the curse. These different states have different buffs and debuffs associated with them. While some of the buffs are handy, make no mistake that the curse is *never* a good thing to have. There are some random musings on the wiki that says the "true power" of the Crimson Curse comes out when in Bloodlust, which increases your character's speed and gives a sizable +25% damage boost. However it's a bit daft to imply there's any real benefit here, because when in Bloodlust your character has a high chance of acting without your instructions, dealing stress damage to the entire party, changing the party's order, denying buffs/heals, or attacking fellow party members. These occur enough where they most certainly do not make the +25% damage worth it, since about 50% of the time your character is going to just do something against the plan. In other words, there is really no upside to having the Crimson Curse - just different ways it can mess with you.

While I do like the general mechanic of the curse, I can't say I enjoyed the new Courtyard levels. They are very long, but not in the tense exploratory sense like the Darkest Dungeon stages - rather they just feel like a tedious march. The length isn't where the tedium comes in, it's the back tracking - there are multiple dead ends and locked doors requiring keys found at other dead ends. This means you'll spend an hour working your way one direction, only to realize you actually should have been working a different direction and have to backtrack to the other side of the level through already cleared hallways. I think the intent here was to make it so you had to carefully manage your characters lust for blood during these missions, but it's just kind of.....boring. You could reference a map on the wiki and have an easier time, but I chose to go in "clean" and see what happened. It probably wasn't really worth it in retrospect though, spending more time navigating the Courtyard wasn't really a highlight of my playthrough.

The Fanatic mini-boss is a cool concept and I don't mind a tough fight, but he is a very risky fight and the payoff for killing him is way out of proportion to the risk for taking him on. There's basically no reason you would willingly want to face him, whereas the Shambler, Collector, and Thing from the Stars mini-bosses all have considerable payoffs you'll get only from them, to the point where you would at times actually want to hunt them down. You'll never want to hunt for the Fanatic though - again maybe that's the point, but it just doesn't feel right compared to the balance of the rest of the game. It would have been far better if he had a few intensely powerful trinkets you could *only* get from a fight with him, rather than just being a source of random trinkets you could also just get from many other places in the game.

The new Crimson Court trinkets are fun, and the way they get additional bonuses when both worn means some of them can really make a great combo. However I found that I tended to use the trinkets from the base game quite a bit more often with few exceptions. Some pairings are very close to being fantastic but still fall short of more traditional pairings, which is I think a real shame.

That's a fair amount of negativity, but overall I did enjoy the addition to the game. It's just that while I would give vanilla Darkest Dungeon a solid A, I'd give this maybe a C+. A passing grade, but nothing to brag about.
